raw_text:
Ex-PM Lord Callaghan dies aged 92
 
 Former Labour prime minister Lord Callaghan has died on the eve of his 93rd birthday.
 
 He passed away at home in East Sussex, just 11 days after his wife Audrey died aged 91. Lord Callaghan, who leaves a son and two daughters, was the longest living former British PM in history. He entered Downing Street in 1976 after the resignation of Harold Wilson. Prime Minister Tony Blair called him a "giant" of the Labour movement. He held each of the major offices of chancellor, home secretary, foreign secretary and prime minister during his career and became Lord Callaghan of Cardiff in 1987.
 
 Chancellor Gordon Brown said the former PM would be "mourned throughout the world". "It was a commitment to public service that brought Jim Callaghan into Parliament in 1945, and while Jim rose to the top he never forgot his roots." Former cabinet colleague Lord Hattersley said his first reaction on hearing the news was "immense sadness".
 
 "It was not a major surprise - I knew what a blow the death of his wife Audrey was a few days ago," he said. "He was a decent kindly man who helped me and my generation of politicians immensely.
 
 "The Labour party and the country will be poorer without him." Conservative peer Lord Heseltine said that despite their political differences, he and Lord Callaghan became friends. "You don't get to the premiership unless you have a streak of determination," he said. "But I saw the other side of Jim Callaghan, he became a personal friend in a way, and my family and I were very fond of him." Tory leader Michael Howard said he would be remembered with "affection and respect". Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy said: "When I was first elected in 1983 as the youngest MP, he was the "Father of the House" and as such took a very keen interest in my early days in Parliament.
 
 "He was always full of warmth and wisdom." Born in 1912 and educated at Portsmouth Northern Secondary School, Lord Callaghan became a clerk at the Inland Revenue. He enlisted in the Royal Navy in 1942 and rose to the rank of lieutenant. Elected for a Cardiff constituency at the 1945 general election, he represented Cardiff seats for more than 40 years. After serving as a junior minister in the Attlee government, he became chancellor of the exchequer when Labour returned to power in 1964.
 
 With sterling under pressure, he resisted devaluation for three years, before being forced into it in 1967. His political career was not without controversy. When he refused to support prime minister Harold Wilson and Dame Barbara Castle over the latter's trade union manifesto, In Place of Strife, in 1968, he said: "I am not going to resign. They will have to throw me out". When home secretary, he ordered British troops to march into the streets of Belfast to protect Catholic civilians amid rising violence - a decision that has dominated British politics into the 21st century.
 
 As foreign secretary in the early 1970s, Lord Callaghan kept an open mind about the UK's entry into the Common Market, seeing the advantages of the UK's entry. He once travelled to Idi Amin's Uganda in 1975 to plead for the life of a British lecturer, Dennis Hills, who was under a death sentence for treason.
 
 His political life was often tempered by battles against the hard left of the party. In the autumn of 1978, before the "Winter of Discontent" when trade unions carried out strikes that brought the country to a standstill, Lord Callaghan refused to hold an early election which may have delivered a Labour victory. As garbage lay uncollected in the streets and hospital staff, council workers and even gravediggers stayed off work, Lord Callaghan failed to predict the mood of the country. When Britain went to the polls in 1979, Tory leader Margaret Thatcher was swept into power in a landslide victory, and Lord Callaghan resigned as Labour leader.
llama3.2:1b: Lord Callaghan dies at 92 after wife's death
llama3.2:3b: Lord Callaghan, former Labour prime minister, died at 92 on the eve of his 93rd birthday. He held all major UK offices before becoming PM in 1976, leaving behind a son and two daughters. Tony Blair described him as a "giant" of the Labour movement. Key figures from both sides of the aisle mourned his passing, with many praising his commitment to public service and his role in shaping British politics.
gemma2:2b: Jim Callaghan, former British Prime Minister, passed away at age 92.  He held numerous political offices throughout his career, including being the longest-living former PM in history. He earned respect for his public service and was remembered fondly by colleagues from across the political spectrum.  His legacy includes controversial decisions like resisting devaluation of sterling in the face of pressure and leading British troops to Belfast during escalating violence.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Former British PM Jim Callaghan, 93, passed away on the eve of his birthday. He left a son and two daughters, though he is survived by an extended family. The former Prime Minister held all major government offices during his career, including Chancellor Gordon Brown, Home Secretary Tony Blair, Foreign Secretary Lord Hattersley, and Prime Minister Tony Blair. He was known for his public service as well as his personal friendship with former Labour Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Former British Prime Minister Lord Callaghan, 92, dies following wife's death at age 93. Known for his longevity and work ethic within the Labour party, he served as Chancellor, Home Secretary, Foreign Secretary, and Prime Minister from 1976 to 1980. His political career was marked by controversy, including opposing trade union policy in 1968 and being forced into devaluation during a crisis.
qwen2.5:3b: Former Labour prime minister Lord Callaghan died at age 92 on the eve of his 93rd birthday, just days after his wife Audrey passed away. He was the longest living former British PM, having entered Downing Street in 1976 following Harold Wilson's resignation. Known for his public service commitment and career spanning various roles including chancellor, home secretary, foreign secretary, and prime minister, he became Lord Callaghan of Cardiff in 1987. Prime Minister Tony Blair called him a "giant" of the Labour movement. He was survived by a son and two daughters. Former cabinet members described him as a kind man who helped them during their political careers; Conservative leader Michael Howard remembered him with affection and respect, while Liberal Democrat Charles Kennedy highlighted his mentorship role in early years of his parliamentary career. Callaghan's life included service in the Royal Navy, representation of Cardiff for over four decades, and significant roles in government policies such as resisting devaluation of sterling and overseeing British troops in Northern Ireland.
opencoder:1.5b:
"Former Labour prime minister Lord Callaghan has died on the eve of his 93rd birthday.
 
 He passed away at home in East Sussex, just 11 days after his wife Audrey died aged 91. Lord Callaghan, who leaves a son and two daughters, was the longest living former British PM in history. He entered Downing Street in 1976 after the resignation of Harold Wilson. Prime Minister Tony Blair called him a "giant" of the Labour movement. He held each of the major offices of chancellor, home secretary, foreign secretary and prime minister during his career and became Lord Callaghan of Cardiff in 1987. 

 He passed away with a heartfelt message that he was a decent kind and would never forget his roots. His death sparked heated debate among his supporters who said they were all so bored by his death. They also expressed their disappointment as the Labour party had been unable to reach a decision on climate change. However, despite these arguments, Lord Callaghan became friends with his family. Despite his political differences and differences with other voters, he remained committed to the country's future despite the loss of support from the critics.

 He was remembered with an equally heartfelt memory as he passed away. His death signaled a moment of peace and solace for everyone involved. With his memory fading into obscurity, the Lord of the House had to step down as well.".

Lord Callaghan, former British Prime Minister and former Labour leader, passed away on the eve of his 93rd birthday at home in East Sussex, just 11 days after his wife Audrey's death at 91. Lord Callaghan was the longest living former British PM in history, holding significant political positions such as Chancellor, Home Secretary, Foreign Secretary, and Prime Minister. He faced controversial decisions during his career, including resisting Harold Wilson's manifesto in 1968 and traveling to Uganda for a case involving British lecturer Dennis Hills. His passing is a significant loss for Labour and the country, as he was seen as a key leader of the Labour movement. Lord Callaghan's legacy includes helping many politicians and families fondly remember his memory.
tinyllama:1.1b: Ex-PM Lord Callaghan has passed away at home in East Sussex at the age of 92 after his wife Audrey died earlier this month. He was the longest-living former British PM, holding each major office of chancellor, home secretary, foreign secretary, and prime minister during his career. Former cabinet colleague Lord Hattersley described the passing of Lord Callaghan as "immense sadness" and noted that he had helped him through the difficult years when Britain went to a landslide victory for Margaret Thatcher. Conservative peer Lord Heseltine described Lord Callaghan as a kind, personal friend who was fond of his family and friends. The Labour party and the country are reported to be in mourning following Lord Callaghan's death.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Ex-PM Lord Callaghan, who held the top political office of Downing Street from 1976 to 1987 after the death of his wife Audrey, passed away at home in East Sussex on Tuesday evening. He was 92 years old. His passing marks the end of a long political career and will be remembered for his commitment to public service and contributions to the Labour Party during his time as prime minister. Lord Callaghan was born in 1912, educated at Portsmouth Northern Secondary School, and went on to become a clerk at the Inland Revenue. After serving in various positions within the government, he became chancellor of the exchequer when Labour returned to power in 1964. During his time in office, he faced many controversies, including refusing to support devaluation for three years and supporting trade union manifestoes like In Place of Strife. As foreign secretary, Lord Callaghan visited Uganda under the patronage of Queen Elizabeth II in 1975 to plead for the life of a British lecturer, Dennis Hills, who was under a death sentence for treason. Despite these battles with the left, Lord Callaghan remained a prominent figure within his party and will be remembered for his contributions to public service during his time as prime minister.
phi:2.7b: Former Prime Minister Lord Callaghan has passed away at the age of 92 on his 93rd birthday. He served as chancellor, home secretary, foreign secretary and prime minister during his career and became known for his commitment to public service. His wife Audrey also recently passed away, leaving their son and two daughters behind. Lord Callaghan was the longest living former British Prime Minister and will be mourned throughout the world.

Callaghan was the longest-living former British PM in history and had remained active in politics even after leaving Downing Street. His career as a politician spanned over four decades, during which he held various major offices of chancellor, home secretary, foreign secretary and prime minister. He was known for his commitment to public service and became Lord Callaghan of Cardiff in 1987.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
Lord James Douglas-Hamilton Callaghan, former British Prime Minister (1976-1979), died at age 92 on April 25, 2023, just 11 days after his wife Audrey's passing. Born in 1912, he was the longest-living former Labour PM. Callaghan served as chancellor, home secretary, foreign secretary, and prime minister throughout his career, holding each role for multiple terms. He entered politics in 1945 and represented Cardiff constituencies for over four decades. His tenure as prime minister was marked by significant events, including opposition to the 1967 devaluation of sterling and his refusal to call an early election during the "Winter of Discontent" in 1978, which led to Margaret Thatcher's landslide victory.

Callaghan was celebrated for his commitment to public service by various former leaders, including Tony Blair, Gordon Brown, Lord Hattersley, and Lord Heseltine. His passing is mourned globally, with colleagues acknowledging the impact of his decades-long political career and personal kindness on the Labour party and the nation.
